content: The Act titled "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" designates and provides assistance for high-intensity interstate gang activity areas under Title XV of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" defines key terms such as Governor, high-intensity interstate gang activity area, and State. The Attorney General, in consultation with Governors, may designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas. The Attorney General, in consultation with Governors, may designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas for Federal assistance in coordinating investigations and enforcement efforts with a criminal street gang enforcement team consisting of Federal, State, and local law enforcement authorities. The Attorney General, in consultation with Governors, may designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas for Federal assistance in coordinating investigations and enforcement efforts with a criminal street gang enforcement team consisting of Federal, State, and local law enforcement authorities. This includes the establishment of teams, reassignment of personnel, and providing necessary funding for operations. The Attorney General, in consultation with Governors, may designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas for Federal assistance in coordinating investigations and enforcement efforts with a criminal street gang enforcement team. The team will consist of agents and officers from various law enforcement authorities and will receive necessary funding for operations and meetings to ensure effective operation through intelligence sharing and best practices. Each criminal street gang enforcement team established shall consist of agents and officers from various law enforcement agencies at the federal, state, and local levels, including the FBI, DEA, ATF, US Marshals, DHS, HUD, and prosecutors. The Attorney General considers criteria for designating high-intensity interstate gang activity areas, including levels of gang crime activity, the relationship between violent crime and gang activity, and involvement of state and local law enforcement. The Attorney General considers criteria for designating high-intensity interstate gang activity areas, including levels of gang crime activity, resource allocation by state and local law enforcement, potential impact of increased federal resources, and any other relevant criteria. Additionally, the Attorney General is authorized to hire up to 94 additional Assistant United States Attorneys. The Attorney General may designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas based on various criteria, including levels of gang crime activity and resource allocation. Up to 94 additional Assistant U.S. Attorneys can be hired for this purpose, with funding authorized as needed. SEC. 3. Grants to state and local prosecutors to combat violent crime and protect witnesses and victims of crimes. Grants under the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 are amended to hire more prosecutors, provide technology and training for accurate identification of gang members and violent offenders, and reduce backlogs. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to fund technology, equipment, and training for prosecutors to increase the accurate identification and successful prosecution of young violent offenders. Authorization of appropriations for $20,000,000 annually from 2008 to 2012 is granted to establish state-wide crime prevention databases for state and local law enforcement under the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. Subtitle I of title XXXII of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 authorizes grants to State and local law enforcement for establishing State-wide crime prevention databases to track criminals, arrests, prosecutions, and convictions. The Office of Justice Programs will award grants for this purpose, with necessary appropriations authorized.
